item.content:encoded:
Slaveholders in Congress, pension plans, journal editors, radio on the internet, and chocolate bar reviews.

Â 

ğŸ‘‹ Some updates: After nearly eight (very fulfilling) years as BuzzFeed Newsâ€™ data editor, Iâ€™m shifting roles there â€” Iâ€™ll be working part-time (for now) on a new initiative that Iâ€™m quite excited about. More details on that soonish. In the meantime, two related developments: âœ¨ weâ€™re hiring a new data editor âœ¨ (ask me about it!) and Iâ€™ve added a âœ¨ job board âœ¨ to Data Is Plural (see below).

Â 

Slaveholders in Congress. At least â€œ1,715 members of Congress were enslavers at some point in their adult lives,â€ according to a Washington Post investigation published Monday. Reporter Julie Zauzmer Weil began her research with a list of every person who ever served in the House or Senate, filtered it to those born before 1840, and then consulted their biographies, Census records, and other historical documents. The Postâ€™s public dataset, the first of its kind, lists the congressmen from that era, their dates of birth, positions held in Congress, states served, dates served, and whether the Post determined they were slaveholders. For 677 of the congressmen, the Post â€œcouldnâ€™t reach a conclusionâ€ and is seeking assistance from readers.

Â 

Pension plans. Public Plans Data, a collaboration led by Boston College professor Alicia H. Munnell, gathers extensive information about the retirement plans that state and local governments offer their employees, drawn from those plansâ€™ annual financial reports. The project maintains a range of datasets, including two decades of participation and financial figures for 200+ plans that account for â€œ95 percent of public pension membership and assets nationwide,â€ their investments, early payout options, and more. It also provides interactive tools and an API.

Â 

Journal editors. For his Open Editors project, Andreas Nishikawa-Pacher scrapes the websites of scholarly journals, extracting the names, affiliations, and roles of their listed editors and board members. The projectâ€™s dataset contains half a million associations between editors and 6,000+ scholarly journals from 22 publishers (17 mainstream and 5 â€œpredatoryâ€). Read more: Nishikawa-Pacher et al.â€™s introductory working paper. And: â€œWhy researchers created a database of half a million journal editorsâ€ (Nature Index, 2021).

Â 

Radio on the internet. Radio-browser.info is â€œa community driven effort (like wikipedia) with the aim of collecting as many internet radio and TV stations as possible.â€ The 29,000+ stations span 200+ countries and 280+ languages. You can explore them on a map, through an API, and via bulk database snapshots. [h/t jlkuester7]

Â 

Chocolate bar reviews. The Manhattan Chocolate Societyâ€™s Brady Brelinski has reviewed 2,500+ bars of craft chocolate since 2006, and compiles his findings into a copy-paste-able table that lists each barâ€™s manufacturer, bean origin, percent cocoa, ingredients, review notes, and numerical rating. Related: Craft chocolate makers in the US and Canada, also compiled by Brelinski. [h/t Andrew MaranhÃ£o]

item.description: Civil asset forfeiture, joint military exercises, medical drug names, foundation shades, and honey bees.
item.content:encoded:
Civil asset forfeiture, joint military exercises, medical drug names, foundation shades, and honey bees.

Â 

Civil asset forfeiture. â€œMost states and the federal government have laws allowing police and prosecutors to seize and permanently keep Americansâ€™ cash, cars, homes and other property suspected of being involved in a crime â€” without regard to the ownersâ€™ guilt or innocence,â€ the nonprofit law firm Institute for Justice writes in its third edition of Policing for Profit, published in 2020. The report gathers and analyzes datasets on property seized in dozens of states through this practice of civil asset forfeiture, and on the spending of forfeiture funds. It also examines seizures from the federal Consolidated Asset Tracking System, detailed public extracts of which the Department of Justice updates quarterly. As seen in: â€œCops still take more stuff from people than burglars doâ€ (The Why Axis, 2021), and â€œStop and Seizeâ€ (Washington Post, 2014).

Â 

Joint military exercises. Jordan Bernhardtâ€™s Joint Military Exercises Dataset describes 5,000+ such operations undertaken between 1977 and 2016, drawn from historical news reports. The dataset lists each exerciseâ€™s name, location, when it began and ended, the countries that participated, activities involved, and more. Related: Brandon J. Kinneâ€™s Defense Cooperation Agreement Dataset, a â€œcomprehensive, human-coded datasetâ€ covering bilateral defense treaties between 1980 and 2010.

Â 

Medical drug names. To build their International Drug Dictionary, Mohammad A. Khaleel et al. collected trade names and ingredient names â€œfrom open access websites belonging to official drug regulatory agencies, official healthcare systems, or recognized scientific bodies from 44 countries around the world,â€ among other sources. Each of the 450,000+ entries maps a name to standardized ingredient information from the National Library of Medicineâ€™s RxNorm database.

Â 

Foundation shades. For â€œThe Naked Truth,â€ a Pudding article published last year with Ofunne Amaka, Amber Thomas scraped information about 6,800+ foundation shades from the websites of two major cosmetics retailers. The projectâ€™s datasets identify each productâ€™s name, description, URL, and the predominant RGB/HSL color value in its swatch image.

Â 

Honey bees. Since the 1980s, the US Department of Agriculture has conducted an annual Bee and Honey Inquiry Survey, which generates estimates of â€œthe number of colonies producing honey, yield per colony, honey production, average price, price by color class and value as well as honey stocks at the state and national levels.â€ Since 2016, it has also published annual reports that examine the gain and loss of colonies, including losses due to colony collapse disorder.

Â

item.description: Local mortality and the 1918 pandemic, religious congregations, COVID-era news layoffs, leadersâ€™ economic persuasions, and root traits.
item.content:encoded:
Local mortality and the 1918 pandemic, religious congregations, COVID-era news layoffs, leadersâ€™ economic persuasions, and root traits.

Â 

Local mortality and the 1918 pandemic. Martin Eiermann, Elizabeth Wrigley-Field, et al. have conducted an analysis of deaths before, during, and after the 1918 influenza pandemic, drawing on â€œdata from multiple sources, including digitized mortality records for 70 U.S. cities, linked census records that establish urban residency status across multiple censusesâ€ and newspaper accounts of non-pharmaceutical interventions. The teamâ€™s published files includes a dataset that, for each city-and-year, lists the mortality rate overall, for white vs. non-white residents, and due to flu/pneumonia; a range of demographic variables; the timing of certain interventions; and more.

Â 

Religious congregations. The Association of Religion Data Archives, founded in 1997, â€œstrives to democratize access to the best data on religion.â€ Among its resources are four waves of the National Congregations Study, a Duke Universityâ€“based survey that asks US religious establishments about their denominational affiliation, buildings of worship, congregants, staffing, educational offerings, and more. Representatives from 5,300+ Christian, Jewish, Muslim, Buddhist, Hindu, and other congregations participated in the latest wave, conducted in 2018â€“19. [h/t Patricia Homan and Amy Burdette + Kevin Lewis]

Â 

COVID-era news layoffs. â€œAt least 6,154 news organization workers, which includes both editorial and non-editorial staffers, were laid off beginning March 2020 through August 2021,â€ according to a new report from the Tow Centerâ€™s Gabby Miller. An interactive tracker provides a map and downloadable table of the layoffs and other cutbacks, listing each outletâ€™s name, medium, owner, and location; the cutbackâ€™s date, description, and category (layoffs, pay cuts, etc.); and source links. Related: The Washington Post Magazineâ€™s Lost Local News issue.

Â 

Leadersâ€™ economic persuasions. Political scientist Bastian Herreâ€™s new Global Leader Ideology dataset â€œprovides unprecedented coverage of chief executivesâ€™ [economic] ideologies across time and space,â€ classifying their approaches as leftist, centrist, rightist, or non-ideological in 182 countries, from 1945 to 2020. Read more: Herreâ€™s introductory paper and Twitter thread.

Â 

Root traits. Oak Ridge National Laboratoryâ€™s Fine-Root Ecology Database categorizes the root characteristics of 4,500+ plant species, as observed and published in scientific literature. The hundreds of types of traits relate to vessel density, root angles, lifespan, macronutrients, microbial symbionts, and more.

Â

item.description: Tobacco habits, working hours, COVID-19 in European prisons, California water wells, and toothbrushing.
item.content:encoded:
Tobacco habits, working hours, COVID-19 in European prisons, California water wells, and toothbrushing.

Â 

Tobacco habits. Every few years since 1992, the National Cancer Institute has sponsored the Tobacco Use Supplement to the Current Population Survey, administered by the US Census Bureau. In addition to extensive demographic information, the supplement asks about historical tobacco usage (â€œHave you smoked at least 100 cigarettes in your entire life?â€), preferences (â€œDo you usually smoke menthol or non-menthol cigarettes?â€), purchasing habits, e-cigarettes, and much more. Anonymized responses and documentation are available for all survey waves through 2018â€“19. Previously: The CDCâ€™s Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (DIP 2016.09.14). [h/t Christian Gunadi et al. + Kevin Lewis]

Â 

Working hours. Political scientist Magnus Bergli Rasmussen has compiled data on the regulation of laborersâ€™ total work hours in nearly every country since 1789, available as a Stata file. For each year and territory, the dataset indicates whether such laws existed, the â€œnormalâ€ number of contractually-obligated weekly hours, the maximum number of hours allowed, and increases in pay for overtime. Read more: â€œThe Great Standardization: Working Hours Around the World,â€ in which Rasmussen describes the datasetâ€™s construction.

Â 

COVID-19 in European prisons. A collaboration coordinated by Deutsche Welle and the European Data Journalism Network has gathered data on the pandemicâ€™s impact on prisoners and prison staff in dozens of European countries, including the number of COVID-19 tests, cases, and deaths over time. The data also note the types of preventative measures and vaccine policies in place. Previously: US prison COVID-19 data from the Marshall Project and AP (DIP 2020.05.06) and the New York Times (DIP 2021.04.21). [h/t Lorenzo Ferrari]

Â 

California water wells. Domestic wells in the San Joaquin Valley â€œare drying up at an alarming paceâ€ amid â€œa frenzy of new well construction and heavy agricultural pumping,â€ according to a Los Angeles Times article last week. Data reporter Gabrielle LaMarr LeMeeâ€™s analysis provides the quantitative backbone, drawing on three state datasets: well completion reports and periodic groundwater level measurements, both of which go back more than a century, and household water supply shortage reports since 2013.

Â 

Toothbrushing. Zawar Hussain et al. recorded data from 120 electric and manual toothbrushing sessions, using sensors attached to the brush handle and brusherâ€™s wrist. Each sessionâ€™s data files trace the sensorsâ€™ positions over time and indicate the brush type, participantâ€™s gender, age, and handedness, and more.

Â

item.description: Faster-turnaround mortality data, zero-day exploits, reproductive assistance in the EU, country leadersâ€™ birthplaces, and 1 million Bandcamp sales.
item.content:encoded:
Faster-turnaround mortality data, zero-day exploits, reproductive assistance in the EU, country leadersâ€™ birthplaces, and 1 million Bandcamp sales.

Â 

Faster-turnaround mortality data. Last week, the CDC began publishing provisional US mortality statistics for 2018 to the near-present. The data are based on death certificates and can be queried by location, timing, demographics, and causes of death. Theyâ€™re similar to the CDCâ€™s non-provisional statistics for earlier years, but â€œwith a lag of just a few weeksâ€ instead of more than a year, writes the COVID-19 Data Dispatchâ€™s Betsy Ladyzhets. Read more: â€œResearchers say the US is undercounting COVID deaths. Now we have a tool to figure out why,â€ an article by Ladyzhets and other members of Documenting COVID-19, who are hosting a webinar about the data today.

Â 

Zero-day exploits. Researchers at Googleâ€™s Project Zero study â€œzero-dayâ€ vulnerabilities â€” software flaws discovered by hackers before they can be fixed. Since 2019, the team has published a spreadsheet of known zero-day exploits â€œin the wild.â€ The spreadsheetâ€™s 200 entries go back to 2014 and note the software product, its vendor, the flawâ€™s type and description, date discovered, date patched, and more. Previously: The Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures list (DIP 2018.12.12). [h/t Patrick Howell Oâ€™Neill + Bruce Schneier]

Â 

Reproductive assistance in the EU. Reporters at Civio have collected data on the access to, and availability of financial aid for, in vitro fertilization and artificial insemination in 43 European countries, noting limits based on age, marital status, sexual orientation, gender identity, and other factors. Read more: â€œMore than half of European countries prohibit access to assisted reproduction for lesbians and almost a third do so for single women.â€ Related: Civioâ€™s visualization code in Observable notebooks. [h/t Olaya ArgÃ¼eso PÃ©rez + Mike Freeman]

Â 

Country leadersâ€™ birthplaces. Axel Dreher et al.â€™s Political Leadersâ€™ Affiliation Database lists the birthplaces and ethnicities of 1,109 leaders of 177 countries between 1989 and 2020. The birthplaces are described at several levels of administrative detail and are ascribed a latitude, longitude, and an indication of those coordinatesâ€™ precision. The ethnicities are drawn from external, linked sources. [h/t Simon HeÃŸ]

Â 

1 million Bandcamp sales. Componentsâ€™ Andrew Thompson has published a dataset of 1,000,000 sales on the music platform Bandcamp during a few weeks in late 2020. For each sale, it includes the itemâ€™s description, price, and type; the buyerâ€™s country; a timestamp; and more. Itâ€™s a slice of the data used in â€œThe Chaos Bazaar: An analysis of Bandcamp sales, 9/1/2020 - 12/31/2020.â€

Â

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2021.12.08 edition
item.description: Citizenship laws, overturned Supreme Court decisions, birds at the feeder, pandemic-era alcohol policies, and a map of our moon.
item.content:encoded:
Citizenship laws, overturned Supreme Court decisions, birds at the feeder, pandemic-era alcohol policies, and a map of our moon.

Â 

Citizenship laws. The Global Citizenship Observatoryâ€™s new Citizenship Law Dataset â€œoutlines, in a systematic way, 28 ways in which citizenship can be acquired and 15 ways in which citizenship can be lost.â€ Launched last week and building on the observatoryâ€™s previous work, it covers the laws in effect in 190 countries in January 2020. For each mode of acquisition or loss in each jurisdiction, the dataset points to the legal citations, specifies the type of procedure (discretionary, automatic, etc.), and describes the relevant conditions (for instance, wedlock requirements for citizenship-by-descent). Previously: Dual citizenship policies (DIP 2019.01.09). [h/t Yajna Govind]

Â 

Overturned Supreme Court decisions. The Library of Congressâ€™s Constitution Annotated project is a â€œcomprehensive, government-sanctioned record of the interpretations of the Constitution,â€ intended for a wide audience and in publication for more than 100 years. Its resources include a table of Supreme Court Decisions overruled by subsequent decisions, with the names and years of the initial and overruling cases, and another of laws held unconstitutional. Read more: The methodologies for both tables. As seen in: â€œHow often are Supreme Court decisions overturned?â€ (Quartz).

Â 

Birds at the feeder. Project FeederWatch is a â€œNovember-April survey of birds that visit backyards, nature centers, community areas, and other locales in North America.â€ Tens of thousands of volunteers record the number and species of birds at each feeder, plus information about the surrounding environment. The results can be explored online and downloaded in bulk. As seen in: â€œWhich birds are the biggest jerks at the feeder?â€ (Washington Post), which uses additional behavioral data collected by the volunteers; and a related Twitter thread. [h/t John Templon]

Â 

Pandemic-era alcohol policies. The US Alcohol Policy Information System has categorized the alcohol-related regulations that each state (and DC) has enforced during the COVID-19 pandemic, and how theyâ€™ve changed over time. The dataset covers January 2020 to mid-September 2021; it examines restrictions on bar and restaurant capacity, serving alcohol without food, alcohol delivery, and more.

Â 

A map of our moon. A USGS astrogeology lab has built a 1:5,000,000-scale map of Earthâ€™s moon, the â€œchief purposeâ€ of which is â€œto summarize the current state of lunar geologic knowledge.â€ It marks thousands of geologic boundaries, plus â€œsurface featuresâ€ such as crater rims, â€œfissures, grabens, scarps, mare wrinkle ridgesâ€ and more. [h/t Wendy Shijia]

Â

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2021.12.01 edition
item.description: The General Index, personal income, banking-crisis interventions, Europeâ€™s primary forests, and Michael Scott misquotes.
item.content:encoded:
The General Index, personal income, banking-crisis interventions, Europeâ€™s primary forests, and Michael Scott misquotes.

Â 

Language from 100 million academic articles. The General Index, a new project from Carl Malamudâ€™s Public Resource, contains detailed linguistic data derived from 107,233,728 academic journal articles. The indexâ€™s main table contains all one-to-five-word sequences found in each article, and their frequencies â€” more than 355 billion â€œn-gramsâ€ in total. A second table identifies nearly 20 billion keywords auto-extracted from the corpus, and a third table lists the authors, title, publication date, and DOI associated with each article. Read more: â€œThe plan to mine the worldâ€™s research papersâ€ (Nature, July 2019) and â€œGiant, free index to worldâ€™s research papers released onlineâ€ (Nature, October 2021). [h/t webmaven]

Â 

Personal income. The US Bureau of Economic Analysis has released its latest county-level estimates of personal income, which now cover 1969â€“2020. The per-capita numbers are also available by metropolitan statistical area, as well as disaggregated by income â€œcomponentâ€ (wages/salaries, income from assets, etc.) and industry. You can download the data and also explore it through interactive tables and maps. As seen in: â€œFrom Wealthy Enclaves to Asset Deserts,â€ a map and report by the Economic Innovation Group.

Â 

Banking-crisis interventions. Economists Andrew Metrick and Paul Schmelzing have compiled a database of 800+ banking crises spanning the years 1257 to 2019, plus 1,800+ government attempts to mitigate them. For each crisis, the database provides the starting year, relevant country or region, a brief description, and more. It also describes the interventions, lists their dates, classifies them into 20 categories (asset guarantees, market liquidity assistance, etc.), and links them to sources and prior literature.

Â 

Europeâ€™s primary forests. Francesco Maria Sabatini et al. have combined information from dozens of sources to develop â€œthe most comprehensive datasetâ€ of Europeâ€™s â€œprimary forestsâ€ â€” those â€œwhere the signs of human impacts, if any, are strongly blurred due to decades without forest management.â€ The dataset, which includes 18,411 patches across 33 countries, describes their names, locations, level of â€œnaturalness,â€ dominant tree species, and more. Previously: EU-Forest (DIP 2017.01.25).

Â 

â€œEarly worm gets the worm.â€ Designer and â€œdiehard Office superfanâ€ Will Chase rewatched the US version of the sitcom with one goal in mind: to document every misquote, malapropism, mispronunciation, and other verbal flub by Steve Carellâ€™s character Michael Scott. He found more than 200.

Â

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2021.11.17 edition
item.description: Carbon credits, foodborne pathogens, violence against environmental defenders, mineral production, and Wernerâ€™s Nomenclature of Colours.
item.content:encoded:
Carbon credits, foodborne pathogens, violence against environmental defenders, mineral production, and Wernerâ€™s Nomenclature of Colours.

Â 

Carbon credits. The Voluntary Registry Offsets Database, a collaboration between the Berkeley Carbon Trading Project and Carbon Direct, â€œcontains all carbon offset projects, credit issuances, and credit retirements listed globally by four major voluntary offset project registries,â€ accounting for â€œalmost all of the worldâ€™s voluntary market offsets.â€ Updated in September with data through early May 2021, the database covers 5,000+ projects and 1.2 billion credits issued. Each credit purportedly offsets a metric tonne of CO2 emissions, but the Berkeley team is skeptical: â€œResearch performed by us and others has found that many, if not most, offset credits traded on the market today do not represent real emissions reductions.â€ Related: The World Bankâ€™s database of carbon pricing initiatives.

Â 

Foodborne pathogens. In an explainer article accompanying a recent food-safety investigation, ProPublica reporter Irena Hwang describes using her training in bioinformatics to analyze salmonella DNA data collected by the National Center for Biotechnology Informationâ€™s Pathogen Detection initiative, which aggregates genomic sequences from bacteria â€œoriginating in food, environmental sources, and patients.â€ The initiative has published such data for nearly 1 million samples of dozens of species. Related: ProPublicaâ€™s Chicken Checker lookup tool, based on the results of Department of Agriculture microbiological sampling conducted at processing plants.

Â 

Violence against environmental defenders. Tierra de Resistentes is a â€œcrossborder journalistic effort to investigate episodes of violence against leaders and communities in Latin America who have devoted their lives to defending the environment.â€ The collaborationâ€™s database details 2,400+ such attacks, mostly focusing on the years 2009â€“2019. For each attack, it provides information about the person, organization, or community attacked, the type of violence, the resource defended, case status, and more. [h/t Juan Pablo MarÃ­n DÃ­az]

Â 

Mineral production. The US Geological Surveyâ€™s National Minerals Information Center keeps tabs on â€œminerals and materials essential to the U.S. economy, the national security, and protection of the environment.â€ Its published datasets include annual statistics on mineral production by state, by country, and by commodity. [h/t Brian C. Keegan]

Â 

Wernerâ€™s Nomenclature of Colours. Data artist Nicholas Rougeux has digitally recreated Scottish painter Patrick Symeâ€™s 1821 guidebook to German mineralogist Abraham Wernerâ€™s color system. For each of the 110 colors, such as Saffron Yellow and Veinous Blood Red, a corresponding spreadsheet contains its name, hex code, description, and more. [h/t Giuseppe Sollazzo]

Â

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2021.11.10 edition
item.description: Toxic pollution, campsite reservations, time zones, NFTs, and damn fine coffees.
item.content:encoded:
Toxic pollution, campsite reservations, time zones, NFTs, and damn fine coffees.

Â 

Toxic pollution. Last week, ProPublica published what itâ€™s calling â€œthe most detailed map of cancer-causing industrial air pollution in the U.S.,â€ along with an investigation based on the mapâ€™s revelations. In a methodology article, reporters explain how they analyzed billions of rows of data from the Environmental Protection Agencyâ€™s Risk-Screening Environmental Indicators model, which â€œtakes a variety of inputs, including emissions data, weather modeling, and facility specific information, and puts out estimated concentrations of toxic chemicals in the air around industrial facilities.â€ The EPA publishes the modelâ€™s output as bulk downloads, in an online dashboard, and in other formats. Related: The model incorporates information from the EPAâ€™s Toxics Release Inventory, which publishes self-reported emissions data from certain mandated industrial facilities.

Â 

Campsite reservations. The US governmentâ€™s Recreation Information Database â€œrepresents an authoritative source of information and services for millions of visitors to federal lands, historic sites, museums, and other attractions/resources.â€ It provides bulk data and an API describing recreational areas, campgrounds, campsites, permit entrances, scheduled tours, and more. You can also download detailed historical data on individual campsite and tour reservations going back to 2006. As seen in: â€œThe Camping Crunch,â€ published by the Center for Western Priorities, and accompanying methodology. [h/t @mtmagog]

Â 

Time zones. The Time Zone Database, used extensively by major operating systems and programming languages, â€œcontains code and data that represent the history of local time for many representative locations around the globe.â€ Its files include detailed notes on sourcing and are â€œupdated periodically to reflect changes made by political bodies to time zone boundaries, UTC offsets, and daylight-saving rules.â€ Read more: â€œExploring 120 years of timezones,â€ by Colin Eberhardt. [h/t Lon Riesberg]

Â 

NFTs. A team developing open-source tools for monitoring cryptocurrency activity has built a dataset of 7 million transactions of non-fungible tokens (NFTs) on the Ethereum blockchain. The dataset covers April to late September 2021, spans 9,000 NFT projects, and records each transactionâ€™s sender, receiver, value, timestamp, and location in the blockchain. Read more: The teamâ€™s analysis. [h/t Ibrahim Ahmed]

Â 

Damn fine coffees. Earlier this year, data visualist Judit Bekker live-blogged her effort to catalog and visualize every coffee consumed in all three seasons of Twin Peaks. Bekkerâ€™s dataset indicates the episode, timestamp, scene, location, circumstances of 258 coffee-drinkings, plus who drank them. [h/t Soph Warnes]

Â

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2021.11.03 edition
item.description: Internet shutdowns, concealed carry licensing, Amazon search results, FOIA reading rooms, and spiders.
item.content:encoded:
Internet shutdowns, concealed carry licensing, Amazon search results, FOIA reading rooms, and spiders.

Â 

Internet shutdowns. A coalition organized by Access Now, a nonprofit that â€œdefends and extends the digital rights of users at risk around the world,â€ has been gathering data on intentional internet shutdowns. It has identified 155 shutdowns in 2020 and 50 in Januaryâ€“May 2021, based on information from a range of sources, including news reports and other trackers, such as the India-focused internetshutdowns.in. The datasets indicate the type of shutdown, start and end dates, geographic scope, who ordered it, public justifications, affected networks, and more. As seen in: â€œInternet shutdowns have become a weapon of repressive regimesâ€ (The Economist).

Â 

Concealed carry licenses. To construct his Concealed Carry Weapons License Database, sociologist Trent Steidley spent â€œover a year collecting data from 28 states using public records requests and cleaning into a state and county-year format.â€ The published files include the raw data, cleaned data, and documentation. The details vary by state, but can include the number of licenses held, issued, denied, revoked, and/or suspended, among other statuses; in some instances, the numbers are also disaggregated by demographic. For most states, the records stretch back to the early 2000s, some even earlier.

Â 

Amazon search results. A recent Markup investigation â€œfound that Amazon places products from its house brands and products exclusive to the site ahead of those from competitors â€” even competitors with higher customer ratings and more sales, judging from the volume of reviews.â€ Reporters Adrianne Jeffries and Leon Yin published their methodology, as well as the underlying code and data, which includes product-placement information relating 12,000+ search queries, details about 157,000+ products, raw HTML, and more.

Â 

FOIA reading rooms. Data librarian Lisa DeLuca has compiled a spreadsheet of 300+ Freedom of Information Act libraries, the online reading rooms where federal agencies must post certain records, including those that â€œare likely to become the subject of subsequent requests for substantially the same records.â€ DeLucaâ€™s spreadsheet, originally published in 2019 and updated last week, lists the agencyâ€™s name, its parent agency, and the portalâ€™s name and URL. [h/t Mago Torres]

Â 

Spiders. The World Spider Catalog is â€œthe first fully searchable online database covering spider taxonomy,â€ with a bulk dataset that lists 49,000+ species, their geographic distributions, and author-year citations. Stano PekÃ¡r et al.â€™s World Spider Trait database collates â€œindividual measurements, observations, or composite characteristics,â€ such as body length, web diameter, and number of egg sacs produced.

Â
